message: I was wondering what (or if ) people are using vim for, other than editing source code. for example: vmail (http://danielchoi.com/software/vmail.html)
out of interest does any one use vmail?

If I am writing ASCII text I am doing it in vim whenever possible. Source code, config files, book manuscripts (I wrote most of my portion of http://withdjango.com in vim/markdown), todo lists, wiki page content, documentation, etc.
i use it for all types of writing with soywiki

I'm consistently toying with the idea of using vmail or mutt to write emails, too. Haven't committed yet but that's mostly due to inertia/laziness/need to do significant amounts of email on non-my systems

Anyone used one of these for todos or just plain text?: http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=2599 http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=2623 http://www.vim.org/scripts/script.php?script_id=2027 ?

@errorhandler I've recently started giving vimwiki a trial run (http://code.google.com/p/vimwiki/) which has some to-do management capabilities. Haven't tried soywiki yet, would be curious to compare it when I have time, but I like how low-friction and self-contained vimwiki is.
I use it to browse the web with Pentadactyl (formerly Vimperator) https://code.google.com/p/dactyl/

I use vim for writing up of my school assignments in markdown, and then converting them to latex pdf documents with pandoc's markdown2pdf utility. It has pretty much replaced bulky word processors for me. Example output: http://static.jb55.com/files/readme.pdf
emacs has vim beat in this regard. I was just reading a blog with a web server that is launched by emacs. http://briancarper.net/blog/510/deploying-clojure-websites

I'd really like to see the taskpaper plugin extended to be a lot more feature rich (ie. support in place boolean filtering like "@week16 and not @done" like the taskpaper.app . Lurv the taskpaper app but I can't tell you the number of days I;'ve had to go back and remove a :w from a line item somewhere... =p And just generally trying to minimize the apps I need open.
@jb55 how did you format that? italics and the subbed characters
@amiamirul pandoc allows you to include inline latex in your markdown documents, so you can do any kind of styling you want really.
